Latest news:

International Restrictions:
*Entry to Ecuador: The land border with Peru remains closed. However, Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents may be allowed to enter Ecuador, via the Huaquillas southern border checkpoint. The land border with Colombia opened in December 2021 to all travellers, but only through the ‘Rumichaca’ international checkpoint, from 8am to 5pm.
Most ports remain closed for travel/tourism activities. As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are permitted in Esmeraldas, Guayaquil, Manta and Puerto Baquerizo ports.
International commercial flights are operating to and from Ecuador. However, we highly recommend you to contact your airline/travel company to check your travel itinerary, in case of any last minute COVID-19-related changes.
As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are authorised at the following ports: Esmeraldas, Manta, Guayaquil and Puerto Bolivar. However, there are strict guidelines and measures to comply with to obtain the relevant permissions.
*Testing / screening on arrival: Upon arrival in Ecuador, all passengers are required to complete a Health Declaration Form with their itinerary and local contact details.
Travellers over 16 years old must present their full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses), received at least 14 days prior the flight date, and a negative RT-PCR test, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding their flight.
Passengers between 2 and 15 years old (15 years, 11 months and 29 days) must present a negative RT-PCR test, taken 72 hours before the flight. The use of Immunity Certificates or Vaccination Certificates/Cards from foreign passengers will be subject to constant review. Passengers in transit are subject to the same requirements as those entering Ecuador. You should arrange to take a private test.
Only children under 2 years old are exempt from the RT-PCR test or the COVID-19 vaccination certificate requirement. Airline crew members are exempt from the above requirements as long as they are not staying overnight in the country.
If, on arrival, a passenger presents COVID-19 related symptoms, they will be required to take a RT-PCR test. If the result is positive, the passenger will be instructed to self-isolate for 14 days.
All passengers arriving from India, including those who only transited the country, must self-isolate for 10 days either in a private home or in a hotel, at their own expense, in addition to meeting the other requirements outlined above.
In response to the omicron variant of COVID-19, since 1 December 2021, passengers arriving from or transiting through South Africa, Botswana, Egypt, Mozambique, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Eswatini (Swaziland) and Namibia are not permitted to enter the country.
Passengers arriving from countries whose regulations state that COVID-19 vaccination is available only after 6 months of having been infected, and who are thus unable to show their full vaccination certificate, will be required to present an official document proving this regulation (valid for 6 months) and a negative RT-PCR test.
*Demonstrating your COVID-19 status: Ecuador will accept the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued in the Crown Dependencies. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
*Quarantine requirements: Passengers who test positive in the antigen test taken at the airport will need to self-isolate for 10 days, from the date of the test. Self-isolation for non-residents can be carried out in any hotel, at their own expense. The full address at which the passenger will self-isolate should be included in the Health Status Declaration Form.
Local residents and people qualified as “priority attention groups” such as people over 65 years old, children and pregnant women, will be allowed to self-isolate at their homes.
The Ministry of Public Health has published more information on coronavirus protocols that also allows for direct messaging with the Ministry (Spanish only).
If you need to find emergency accommodation to go through the mandatory self-isolation protocol, you can access options on the Ministry of Public Health websiteThe Government will monitor the situation in other countries with high risk of contagion to prevent incoming flights.
*Travel to and from the Galapagos: Tourist activities are allowed in the Galapagos Islands.
All travellers over 16 years old wishing to enter the Islands must present a negative (RT-PCR) test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior to the date of the flight to the Galapagos Islands, along with a full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses, or its equivalent), received at least 14 days prior the flight date. The use of “Immunity Certificates or Vaccination Certificates/Cards” from foreign passengers will be subject to constant review.
Children between 2 and 16 years must present a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior embarking the flight. Any passengers presenting COVID-19 related symptoms will be denied entry to the Islands.
National and foreign tourists must also present evidence of a return flight, as well as the Galapagos Transit Control Card, to be filled out online at least 24 hours before the flight. Travel health insurance is mandatory for foreign tourists.
For inter-island travel, all passengers over 12 years must present their complete vaccination certificate.

Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Ecuador: The Ecuadorean government provides coronavirus-related information on the Coronavirus Ecuador website . The Ministry of Public Health (MSP) also provides an information page . However, the most up to date information is accessible via their Twitter account. *Restrictions: The general nationwide biosecurity measures include:
• mandatory COVID-19 vaccination for Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents
• extra precaution advised for the elderly and vulnerable
• mandatory use of face masks in public spaces
• social distancing measures and frequent hand washing
• In-person school classes were suspended in 2020, however most are now taking place again.
• remote working continues to be encouraged
• the reopening of beaches will continue to be monitored via the “Distancia2” app
• a nationwide tracing app ( ̔ASI Ecuador̕ ) is available to alert people if they have been in contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case during the last 15 days. The app is supported via Bluetooth and maintains the confidentiality of users
• the land border with Peru remains closed until further notice. However, Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents may be allowed to enter Ecuador via the Huaquillas southern border checkpoint
• the land border with Colombia opened on 17 December 2021 to all travellers, but only through the ‘Rumichaca’ international check-point, from 8am to 5pm. Standard entry requirements apply.
• most ports remain closed for travel/tourism activities. As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are permitted in Esmeraldas, Guayaquil, Manta and Puerto Baquerizo ports
All people over 12 (including foreign tourists) must present their COVID-19 vaccination card (showing 2 complete doses) to enter any establishment providing non-essential services (for example, but not limited to, banks, shops, supermarkets, restaurants, transport, etc). This rule has also been enforced at airports. This will not apply to public sector institutions and for essential services such as health and education. COVID-19 vaccination certificates are also mandatory for all passengers over 5 years old for all inter-district, interstate, urban and tourist buses.
Since the beginning of January 2022, Ecuador’s National Emergency Operations Committee has urged local authorities to implement the following measures:
• maximum capacity of 75% in fairs, shopping centres, markets, supermarkets (in addition only one person per family may enter at a time), museums, and financial and government establishments;
• maximum capacity of 50% in restaurants, food courts, places of worship, entrepreneurship fairs, cinemas and theatres, gyms, thermal baths and spas; the sale and consumption of food and drinks at cinemas and theatres is not permitted;
• closure of bars, clubs and convention centres, and prohibition of events, including: receptions, concerts, processions and religious events in public spaces;
• strict compliance with biosecurity protocols, use of face mask, frequent hand-washing, appropriate ventilation and social distancing;
• local governments which have beaches/bathing areas to establish a maximum capacity of 75% and opening hours of 06:00 until 18:00;
• maximum capacity of 50% for in-person working, except for strategic sectors. Same recommendation for private entities
Note that COE only makes recommendations, but the power to impose these restrictions rests with local authorities. As a result, you may see some discrepancies between local areas.
The central government´s ‘red, yellow, green’ alert system indicates epidemiological risk, and recommends associated restrictions for high, medium and low risk levels. The district traffic light colours will change weekly.
Red restrictions for 17 to 23 January are as follows:
• maximum public attendance capacity of 30%, with restricted hours, in shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments, public transport, restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres, gyms, thermal baths, spas and higher education establishments. Controlled activities with 30% maximum attendance at beaches, parks and open spaces. Protected areas and national parks will be closed from Monday to Wednesday, and accessible from Thursday to Sunday only within restricted hours
• suspended preschool education
• online classes for primary school education
*Yellow: maximum public attendance capacity of 50% in shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments, public transport, restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres, gyms, thermal baths, spas, beaches, parks, open spaces and higher education establishments
• suspended preschool education
• hybrid classes for primary school education
*Green: maximum public attendance capacity of 75% in shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments, public transport, restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres, gyms, thermal baths and spas, beaches, parks, open spaces and high education establishments
• preschool education aligned to the Ministry of Education’s protocol
• in-person primary school education
Further local restrictions, including vehicle circulation restrictions, are the responsibility of local authorities. These restrictions may change at short notice and vary between different areas, so check regularly for updates (see details below, including the restrictions in place in Quito). The most up to date information can be found via the local authorities’ social media channels:
Quito: @MunicipioQuito; Guayaquil: @alcaldiagye; Cuenca: @MunicipioCuenca; Galapagos: @CGGalapagos.
Ecuador’s National Emergency Operations Committee (COE) has a website with their official resolutions (Spanish only). During the national health emergency, the Ecuadorean Ministry of Health will continue to issue the required health prevention measures, including PCR tests and any mandatory self-isolation (Aislamiento Preventivo Obligatorio – APO) requirements. Visit the Quito “Mariscal Sucre” International Airport website for details on their COVID-19 protocols and health measures for passengers.
Visit the Guayaquil “Jose Joaquin de Olmedo” International Airport website for general information on COVID-19 measures and related FAQ (in Spanish). *Restrictions in Quito: In addition to adhering to the standard general biosecurity measures, you must also carry an identity card at all times.
The “Pico y Placa” system for restricting private vehicle use was reinstated from 4 November 2021.Vehicles with number plates ending in the following numbers will have restrictions on the given days below, and will not be allowed to circulate from 6am to 9.30am and from 4pm to 9pm on the assigned days: Monday: 0, 1; Tuesday: 2, 3; Wednesday 4, 5; Thursday 6, 7 and Friday 8, 9. There are no vehicle restrictions at the weekends or on official public holidays.
“Pico y Placa” does not apply to over 65 year-olds who drive their own vehicle.
